title: 112_hr2662
content: The "Health Equity Act of 2011" includes provisions for deducting health insurance costs in computing self-employment taxes and for qualified health insurance costs of individuals. The Act aims to address health equity issues. The "Health Equity Act of 2011" allows individuals to deduct the amount paid for qualified health insurance coverage for themselves, their spouse, and dependents. Qualified health insurance is defined as insurance that constitutes medical care, with exceptions for certain benefits like vision and dental coverage. The "Health Equity Act of 2011" allows individuals to deduct insurance payments from their taxes, excluding them from deductions under other sections and self-employment tax calculations. The "Health Equity Act of 2011" allows individuals to deduct insurance payments from their taxes, excluding them from deductions under other sections and self-employment tax calculations. Subsection (a) of section 62 of the tax code is amended to include a new paragraph allowing deduction for qualified health insurance costs under section 224. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections, redesignating section 224 as section 225. The amendments made by section 224 apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010. Fitness programs, athletic clubs, equipment, and weight loss programs are considered medical care under section 4. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has been amended to include fitness programs, athletic clubs, fitness equipment, and weight loss programs as eligible for tax benefits under medical care expenses. The amount deductible for these expenses in a taxable year is limited to $1,200. Additionally, Flexible Spending Arrangements and Health Reimbursement Arrangements now cover these expenses as well. The amendment allows for reimbursement of fitness programs, athletic clubs, fitness equipment, and weight loss programs as medical expenses, with a limit of $1,200 per taxable year. Effective starting from taxable years after December 31, 2010.
